{{redirect|Ussher|the surname|Ussher (surname)}} {{short description|17th-century Anglican Archbishop of Armagh}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox Bishop | honorific-prefix = [[The Most Reverend]] | name = James Ussher | nationality = Irish | image=James Ussher by Sir Peter Lely.jpg | religion = [[Church of Ireland]] | see = Armagh | bishop_of = [[Archbishop of Armagh (Church of Ireland)|Archbishop of Armagh]], [[Primate of All Ireland]] | enthroned = 1625 | ended = 1656 | consecration = 1626 | predecessor = [[Christopher Hampton (bishop)|Christopher Hampton]] | successor = [[John Bramhall]] (from 1661) | other_post = Professor, [[Trinity College, Dublin]]
[[Chancellor (ecclesiastical)|Chancellor]], [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin]]
[[Prebendary|Prebend]] of Finglas. | ordination = 1602 | birth_date = 4 January 1581 | birth_place = [[Dublin]], [[Kingdom of Ireland|Ireland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1656|3|21|1581|1|4|df=y}} | death_place = [[Reigate]], Surrey, [[Kingdom of England|England]] | buried = Chapel of St. Erasmus, [[Westminster Abbey]] | alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Dublin]] }} '''James Ussher''' (or '''Usher'''; 4 January 1581 – 21 March 1656) was the [[Church of Ireland]] [[Archbishop of Armagh (Church of Ireland)|Archbishop of Armagh]] and [[Primate of All Ireland]] between 1625 and 1656. He was a prolific scholar and church leader, who today is most famous for his identification of the genuine letters of the church father, Ignatius, and for his chronology that sought to establish the time and date of the [[Genesis creation myth|creation]] as "the entrance of the night preceding the 23rd day of October... the year before Christ 4004"; that is, around 6 pm on 22 October 4004 {{sc|bc}} according to the [[proleptic Julian calendar]]. ==Education== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2016}} Ussher was born in [[Dublin]] to a well-to-do family. His maternal grandfather, [[James Stanihurst]], had been speaker of the [[Irish House of Commons|Irish parliament]]. Ussher's father, Arland Ussher, was a clerk in chancery who married [[James Stanihurst]]'s daughter, Margaret (by his first wife Anne Fitzsimon), who was reportedly a Roman Catholic.{{cite DNB|wstitle=Stanyhurst, Richard|volume=54|first=Sidney|last=Lee}} Ussher's younger, and only surviving, brother, [[Ambrose Ussher|Ambrose]], became a distinguished scholar of [[Arabic]] and [[Hebrew languages|Hebrew]]. According to his chaplain and biographer, [[Nicholas Bernard]], the elder brother was taught to read by two blind, spinster aunts. A gifted [[Polyglot (person)|polyglot]], he entered Dublin Free School and then the newly founded (1591) [[Trinity College, Dublin]] on 9 January 1594, at the age of thirteen (not an unusual age at the time). He had received his Bachelor of Arts degree by 1598, and was a fellow and MA by 1600 (though Bernard claims he did not gain his MA till 1601). In May 1602, he was ordained in the Trinity College Chapel as a deacon in the [[Protestant]], [[state religion|established]], [[Church of Ireland]] (and possibly priest on the same day) by his uncle [[Henry Ussher]], the Archbishop of Armagh and Primate of All Ireland. Ussher went on to become [[Chancellor (ecclesiastical)|Chancellor]] of [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin]] in 1605 and [[Prebendary|Prebend]] of [[Finglas]]. He became Professor of Theological Controversies at Trinity College and a Bachelor of Divinity in 1607, Doctor of Divinity in 1612, and then [[Vice-Chancellor]] in 1615 and vice-provost in 1616. In 1613, he married Phoebe, daughter of a previous [[Provost (education)|Vice-Provost]], Luke Challoner, and published his first work. In 1615, he was closely involved with the drawing up of the first [[confession of faith]] of the Church of Ireland. ==Early life and career== In 1619 Ussher travelled to England, where he remained for two years. His only child was Elizabeth (1619–93), who married [[Sir Timothy Tyrrell]], of [[Oakley, Buckinghamshire]]. She was the mother of [[James Tyrrell (writer)|James Tyrrell]]. He became prominent after meeting [[James I of England|James I]]. In 1621 James I nominated Ussher [[Bishop of Meath]]. He became a national figure in Ireland, becoming [[Privy Councillor]] in 1623 and an increasingly substantial scholar. A noted collector of Irish manuscripts, he made them available for research to fellow-scholars such as his friend, [[Sir James Ware]]. From 1623 until 1626 he was again in England and was excused from his episcopal duties to study church history. He was nominated [[Primate (bishop)|Primate]] of All Ireland and [[Archbishop of Armagh (Church of Ireland)|Archbishop of Armagh]] in 1625 and succeeded [[Christopher Hampton (bishop)|Christopher Hampton]], who had succeeded Ussher's uncle Henry twelve years earlier. ==Primate of All Ireland== {{more citations needed|section|date=March 2016}} [[File:Jacobus ussher.gif|thumbnail|left|Archbishop James Ussher (1581–1656)]] After his consecration in 1626, Ussher found himself in turbulent political times. Tension was rising between England and Spain, and to secure Ireland [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] offered Irish Catholics a series of concessions, including religious toleration, known as [[the Graces (Ireland)|The Graces]], in exchange for money for the upkeep of the army. Ussher was a convinced [[Calvinism|Calvinist]] and viewed with dismay the possibility that people he regarded as anti-Christian papists might achieve any sort of power. He called a secret meeting of the Irish bishops in his house in November 1626, the result being the "Judgement of the Arch-Bishops and Bishops of Ireland". This begins: {{quote|The religion of the papists is superstitious and idolatrous; their faith and doctrine erroneous and heretical; their church in respect of both, apostatical; to give them therefore a toleration, or to consent that they may freely exercise their religion, and profess their faith and doctrine, is a grievous sin.}} The Judgement was not published until it was read out at the end of a series of sermons against the Graces given at Dublin in April 1627. In the end, the Graces were not confirmed by the [[Parliament of Ireland|Irish Parliament]].{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} During a four-year interregnum between Lord Deputies from 1629 on, there was an increase in efforts to impose religious conformity on Ireland. In 1633, Ussher wrote to the new [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[William Laud]], in an effort to gain support for the imposition of [[recusancy]] fines on Irish Catholics. [[Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford|Thomas Wentworth]], who arrived as the new Lord Deputy in Ireland in 1633, deflected the pressure for conformity by stating that firstly, the Church of Ireland itself would have to be properly resourced, and he set about its re-endowment. He settled the long-running primacy dispute between the sees of [[Armagh]] and [[Dublin]] in Armagh's favour. The two clashed on the subject of the theatre: Ussher had the usual Puritan antipathy to the stage, whereas Wentworth was a keen theatre-goer, and against Ussher's opposition, oversaw the foundation of Ireland's first theatre, the [[Werburgh Street Theatre]]. Ussher soon found himself at odds with the rise of [[Arminianism]] and Wentworth and Laud's desire for conformity between the [[Church of England]] and the more Calvinistic [[Church of Ireland]]. Ussher resisted this pressure at a [[convocation]] in 1634, ensuring that the English [[Thirty-Nine Articles|Articles of Religion]] were adopted as well as the Irish articles, not instead of them, and that the Irish [[Canon law|canons]] had to be redrafted based on the English ones rather than replaced by them. Theologically, he was a Calvinist although on the matter of the atonement he was (somewhat privately) a [[hypothetical universalist]]. His most significant influence in this regard was [[John Davenant]], later an English delegate to the [[Synod of Dort]], who managed to significantly soften that Synod's teaching regarding limited atonement.Moore, J.D. (2007) English Hypothetical Universalism, Cambridge: Eerdmans. In 1633, Ussher had supported the appointment of [[William Laud|Archbishop Laud]] as Chancellor of the [[University of Dublin]]. He had hoped that Laud would help to impose order on what was, Ussher accepted, a somewhat mismanaged institution. Laud did that, rewriting the charter and statutes to limit the authority of the fellows, and ensure that the appointment of the provost was under royal control. In 1634, he imposed on the College an Arminian provost, [[William Chappell (bishop)|William Chappell]], whose theological views, and peremptory style of government, were antithetical to everything for which Ussher stood. By 1635, it was apparent that Ussher had lost de facto control of the church to [[John Bramhall]], Bishop of [[Derry]], in everyday matters and to Laud in matters of policy. William M. Abbott, Associate Professor of History at [[Fairfield University]], argues that he was an effective and politically important bishop and archbishop.Abbott, William M. (1990). "James Ussher and "Ussherian" episcopacy, 1640–1656: the primate and his Reduction manuscript." ''Albion'' xxii: 237–259. The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography notes that he was reactive and sought conciliation rather than confrontation.''James Ussher'', [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] (2004) The story that he successfully opposed attempts to reintroduce the [[Irish language]] for use in church services by [[William Bedell]], the Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Kilmore|Kilmore]], has been refuted.O'Sullivan, W. S. (1968). "Review of R. B. Knox, James Ussher Archbishop of Armagh", ''Irish Historical Studies'' xvi: 215–19.Leerssen, J. (1982–1983). "Archbishop Ussher and Gaelic culture", ''Studia Hibernica'' xxii–xxiii: 50–58. Ussher certainly preferred to be a scholar when he could be. He engaged in extensive disputations with Roman Catholic theologians, and even as a student he challenged a [[Jesuit]] relative, [[Henry Fitzsimon]] (Ussher's mother was Catholic), to dispute publicly the identification of the Pope with the [[Antichrist]]. [[File:Rare Small BX 5530 .U8 I4 1643 000005.tif|thumb|right|The title page of "Immanuel, or the Mystery of the Incarnation of the Son of God," authored in 1643.]] However, Ussher also wrote extensively on theology,e.g., [https://archive.org/details/nd613931085/page/n3 "Immanuel, or the mystery of Incarnation of God."] patristics and ecclesiastical history, and these subjects gradually displaced his anti-Catholic work. After Convocation in 1634, Ussher left Dublin for his episcopal residence at [[Drogheda]], where he concentrated on his archdiocese and his research. In 1631, he produced a new edition of a work first published in 1622, his "Discourse on the Religion Anciently Professed by the Irish", a ground-breaking study of the [[Celtic Christianity|early Irish church]], which sought to demonstrate how it differed from Rome and was, instead, much closer to the later Protestant church. This was to prove highly influential, establishing the idea that the Church of Ireland was the true successor of the early Celtic church. In 1639, he published the most substantial history of Christianity in Britain to that date, ''Britannicarum ecclesiarum antiquitates'' — the antiquities of the British churches. It was an astonishing achievement in one respect — in gathering together so many previously unpublished manuscript sources. Ussher was very reluctant to arrive at firm judgements as to the sources' authenticity — hence his devotion of a whole chapter to the imaginative but invented stories of [[King Lucius]] and the creation of a Christian episcopate in Britain. ==English Civil War== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2016}} [[File:James Ussher portrait.jpg|thumb|left|In the years before the [[English Civil War]], James Ussher's reputation as a scholar and his moderate Calvinism meant that his opinion was sought by both King and Parliament.]] In 1640, Ussher left Ireland for England for what turned out to be the last time. In the years before the [[English Civil War]], his reputation as a scholar and his moderate Calvinism meant that his opinion was sought by both King and Parliament. After Ussher lost his home and income through the [[Irish Rebellion of 1641|Irish uprising]] of 1641, Parliament voted him a pension of £400 while the King awarded him the income and property of the vacant [[See of Carlisle]]. Despite their occasional differences, he remained a loyal friend to the [[Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford|Earl of Strafford]], and when the latter was sentenced to death by Parliament, pleaded with the King not to allow the execution of the verdict: unlike some of his episcopal colleagues, he insisted that the King was absolutely bound in conscience by his promise to Strafford that whatever happened his life would be spared. The King did not take his advice, but clearly afterwards regretted not doing so, as is shown by his reference on the scaffold to Strafford's death as "that unjust sentence which I suffered to take effect". In early 1641 Ussher developed a mediatory position on church government, which sought to bridge the gap between the Laudians, who believed that bishops were divinely ordained and a separate order from priests and deacons, and the presbyterians, who wanted to abolish episcopacy entirely. His proposals, not published until 1656, after his death, as The Reduction of Episcopacy, proposed a compromise where bishops operated in a presbyterian [[synodal]] system, were initially designed to support a rapprochement between Charles and the parliamentarian leadership in 1641, but were rejected by the King. They did, however, have an afterlife, being published in England and Scotland well into the eighteenth century. In all, he wrote or edited five books relating to episcopacy; the last two, treatises on the [[Ignatius of Antioch|Ignatian]] epistles, were particular scholarly achievements that have largely survived modern scrutiny. As the middle ground between King and Parliament vanished in 1641–1642, Ussher was forced, reluctantly, to choose between his Calvinist allies in parliament and his instinctive loyalty to the monarchy. Eventually, in January 1642 (having asked parliament's permission), he moved to Oxford, a royalist stronghold. Though Charles severely tested Ussher's loyalty by negotiating with the Catholic Irish, the Primate remained committed to the royal cause, though as king's fortunes waned Ussher had to move on to [[Bristol]], [[Cardiff]], and then to [[St Donat's Castle|St Donat's]]. In June 1646, he returned to London under the protection of his friend, [[John Mordaunt, 1st Earl of Peterborough|Elizabeth, Dowager Countess of Peterborough]], in whose houses he stayed from then on. He became a preacher at [[Lincoln's Inn]] early in 1647, and despite his royalist loyalties was protected by his friends in Parliament. He watched the execution of Charles I from the roof of the Countess of Peterborough's home in London but fainted before the axe fell. ==Chronology== {{main|Ussher chronology}} {{refimprove section|date=January 2016}} Ussher now concentrated on his research and writing and returned to the study of chronology and the [[church fathers]]. After a 1647 work on the origin of the [[Creed]]s, Ussher published a treatise on the calendar in 1648. This was a warm-up for his most famous work, the ''[[Annales veteris testamenti, a prima mundi origine deducti]]'' ("Annals of the Old Testament, deduced from the first origins of the world"), which appeared in 1650, and its continuation, ''Annalium pars posterior'', published in 1654. In this work, he calculated the date of the [[Genesis creation myth|Creation]] to have been nightfall on 22 October 4004 BC. (Other scholars, such as [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] academic, [[John Lightfoot]], calculated their own dates for the Creation.) The time of the [[Ussher chronology]] is frequently misquoted as being 9 a.m., noon or 9 p.m. on 23 October. See the [[Ussher chronology|related article on the chronology]] for a discussion of its claims and methodology. Ussher's work is now used to support [[Young Earth Creationism]], which holds that the universe was created thousands of years ago (rather than billions). But while calculating the date of the Creation is today considered a controversial activity, in Ussher's time such a calculation was still regarded as an important task, one previously attempted by many Post-Reformation scholars, such as [[Joseph Justus Scaliger]] and physicist [[Isaac Newton]]. Ussher's chronology represented a considerable feat of scholarship: it demanded great depth of learning in what was then known of ancient history, including the rise of the Persians, Greeks and Romans, as well as expertise in the Bible, biblical languages, astronomy, ancient calendars and chronology. Ussher's account of historical events for which he had multiple sources other than the Bible is usually in close agreement with modern accounts—for example, he placed the death of [[Alexander the Great|Alexander]] in 323 BC and that of [[Julius Caesar]] in 44 BC. Ussher's last extra-biblical co-ordinate was the Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar, and beyond this point he had to rely on other considerations. Faced with inconsistent texts of the Torah, each with a different number of years between Flood and Creation, Ussher chose the Masoretic version, which claims an unbroken history of careful transcription stretching back centuries—but his choice was confirmed for him, because it placed Creation exactly four thousand years before 4 BC, the generally accepted date for the birth of the 'Jesus' of the Christian faith; moreover, he calculated, Solomon's temple was completed in the year 3000 from creation, so that there were exactly 1000 years from the temple to Jesus, who was thought to be the 'fulfillment' of the Temple.Barr, James. ''Biblical Chronology: Legend Or Science?'' The Ethel M. Wood Lecture 1987. Delivered at the Senate House, University of London on 4 March 1987. London: University of London, 1987, p. 19 {{OCLC|19643211}} Ussher remains extremely popular amongst creationists, even though they reject his methodology of using the most up to date contemporary scientific, chronological, historical and biblical scholarship to date the age of the world. ==Death== [[File:James Ussher.jpg|thumb|James Ussher's reported last words were "O Lord forgive me, especially my sins of omission".]] In 1655, Ussher published his last book, ''De Graeca Septuaginta Interpretum Versione'', the first serious examination of the [[Septuagint]], discussing its accuracy as compared with the Hebrew text of the Old Testament. In 1656, he went to stay in the Countess of Peterborough's house in [[Reigate]], Surrey. On 19 March, he felt a sharp pain in his side after supper and took to his bed. His symptoms seem to have been those of a severe internal haemorrhage. Two days later he died, aged 75. His last words were reported as: "O Lord, forgive me, especially my sins of omission." His body was embalmed and was to have been buried in Reigate, but at [[Oliver Cromwell|Cromwell]]'s insistence he was given a state funeral on 17 April and was buried in the chapel of St Erasmus in [[Westminster Abbey]].[http://www.westminster-abbey.org/our-history/people/james-ussher James Ussher profile], westminster-abbey.org; accessed 1 January 2016. ==Works== *{{Citation |editor-last=Elrington |editor-first=Charles Richard |author-link=Charles Richard Elrington |year=1847 |title=The Whole Works of the Most Rev. {{Infobox video game | title= Joe & Mac 2: Lost in the Tropics | image= [[File:JapaneseJoeandMacBoxArt.jpg|frameless|Joe & Mac 2: Lost in the Tropics]] | caption= Cover art | developer= [[Data East]] | publisher= {{vgrelease|JP|Data East|NA|Data East|EU|[[Elite Systems]]}} | composer= Tatsuya Kiuchi | release= {{vgrelease|JP|February 18, 1994|NA|April 1994|EU|November 1995{{cite web| url = http://www.gamefaqs.com/console/snes/data/588406.html| title = Release information| publisher = [[GameFAQs]]| date = | accessdate = 2010-04-26}}}} | genre= [[Action game|2D action]] [[platform game|platformer]] | modes= [[Single-player video game|Single-player]]
[[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] | platforms= [[Super NES]] }} '''''Joe & Mac 2: Lost in the Tropics''''' - released in Japan as {{nihongo|'''''Tatakae Genshijin 3: Shuyaku wa yappari Joe & Mac'''''|ジョー アンド マック 戦え原始人3 主役はやっぱりJOE & MAC||}},{{cite web | url = http://superfamicom.org/info/tatakae-genshijin-3-shuyaku-ha-yappari-joe-and-mac| title = Japanese-English title translation| publisher = SuperFamicom.org| date = | accessdate = 2012-07-28}} and in Europe as '''''Joe & Mac 3: Lost in the Tropics''''' - is a [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]] video game and a sequel to ''[[Joe & Mac]]''. It is the follow-up to ''[[Congo's Caper]]'', the second game in the series. ==Gameplay== A caveman named Gork has stolen the [[Crown (headgear)|crown]] belonging to the [[Tribal chief|Chief]] of Kali Village, and it's up to the player to retrieve it by using the seven [[rainbow]] stones that he will receive in the story.{{cite web | url = http://www.mobygames.com/game/joe-mac-2-lost-in-the-tropics| title = Story overview/additional release information| publisher = [[MobyGames]]| date = | accessdate = 2010-04-27}} [[File:JoeandMac2BossBattleScrenShotSNES.jpg|200px|left|thumb|A two-player match against an ''Elasmosaurus''.]] The object of the game is to defeat [[Neanderthal]]s with two caveman ninja heroes along with [[dinosaur]]s and huge level [[boss (video games)|boss]]es. Each player controls either Joe or Mac with limited lives and continues. Players can also choose to fall in love with a [[girlfriend]] in their [[Stone Age]] village; giving her flowers and meat as presents. Once the player gets married, he gets to father a child. Stone wheels are the official currency in the game and players can replay levels in order to get more stone wheels. An overhead free roam map offers a chance for players to select their level like they were playing a console role-playing game. The action-packed levels are in side view.{{cite web | url = http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/joeandmac/joeandmac2.htm| title = Advanced story overview| publisher = Hard Core Gaming 101| date = | accessdate = 2010-04-29}} Boss enemies include ''[[Stegosaurus]]'', ''[[Pteranodon]]'', ''[[Triceratops]]'', ''[[Elasmosaurus]]'', and ''[[Tyrannosaurus]]''. After defeating each boss, the player will earn one of the rainbow stones. During the game, friendly creatures such as ''Pteranodon'', ''[[Styracosaurus]]'' and ''[[Plesiosaurus]]'' will give the player a ride. The game features six levels, including a valley, a jungle, a snowy mountain range, a swamp, and a volcano. In the final level, the player must defeat each of the boss enemies a second time before battling Gork. When Gork is defeated, he gains power from the crown and turns into a [[warthog]] demon. When Gork is defeated a second time, the player will earn the crown and end the game. ==Reception== ''[[GamePro]]'' gave the game a moderately positive review, commenting that "If you already like Joe and his buddy Mac, you'll like 'em even more after playing this long, colorful game."{{cite news|last= |first= |title=ProReview: Joe & Mac 2: Lost in the Tropics|work=[[GamePro]]|issue=58|publisher=[[International Data Group|IDG]]|date=May 1994|page=74}} In 2011, [[IGN]] listed the game as number 61 on their list of the top 100 SNES video games.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/top/snes-games/61|title=Top 100 Super Nintendo (SNES) Video Games {{ndash}} Joe & Mac 2: Lost in the Tropics|publisher=[[IGN]]|year=2011|access-date=2016-05-06}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://superfamicom.org/info/tatakae-genshijin-3-shuyaku-ha-yappari-joe-and-mac/ ''Tatakae Genshijin 3 - Shuyaku ha Yappari - Joe & Mac''] at superfamicom.org * [http://www.super-famicom.jp/data/ta/ta_0045.html ''戦え原始人3 / Tatakae Genshijin 3''] at super-famicom.jp {{jp icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Joe and Mac 2: Lost in the Tropics}} [[Category:1994 video games]] [[Category:Data East video games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:Prehistoric people in popular culture]] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System-only games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games set in prehistory]] [[Category:Neanderthals in fiction]] [[Category:Dinosaurs in video games]] [[ja:戦え原始人#戦え原始人3 主役はやっぱりJOE&MAC]]

[[Queer studies]] | movement = | notableworks = ''Asexualities: Feminist and Queer Perspectives'' (2014) | spouse = | partner = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''KJ Cerankowski''' is an American professor and author whose work focuses on [[gender]] and [[human sexuality]] with a focus on [[Asexuality|asexuality studies]]. They are an assistant professor of Comparative American Studies and Gender, Sexuality, and Feminist Studies at [[Oberlin College]]. With Megan Milks, they co-edited ''Asexualities: Feminist and Queer Perspectives'' ([[Routledge]], 2014). ==Education and career== Cerankowski received a Ph.D. in Modern Thought and Literature at [[Stanford University]] in 2014;{{cite web|last1=Stark|first1=Leah|title=Shedding light on asexuality|url=https://medicalxpress.com/news/2015-02-asexuality.html|website=Medical Xpress|accessdate=5 June 2017|date=24 February 2015}} they completed a dissertation entitled ''Illegible: asexualities in media, literature, and performance'' analyzing the cultural significance of asexuality as "a queer way of thinking about sexual subjectivity, desire, and intimacy."{{Cite thesis |chapter= |title=Illegible: asexualities in media, literature, and performance |url= https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/10580628 |last=Cerankowski |first=Karli June |publisher=[[Stanford University]] |accessdate= 5 June 2017|date=July 2014}} Cerankowski is an assistant professor of Comparative American Studies and Gender, Sexuality, and Feminist Studies at [[Oberlin College]].{{cite web|title=KJ Cerankowski {{!}} Oberlin College and Conservatory|url=https://www.oberlin.edu/kj-cerankowski|website=Oberlin College and Conservatory|accessdate=6 September 2017|language=en|date=24 August 2017}} Before joining the Oberlin faculty, they were a lecturer in the department of Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies at [[Stanford University]] and a fellow at the Clayman Institute for Gender Research.{{cite web|title=Karli Cerankowski {{!}} The Clayman Institute for Gender Research|url=http://gender.stanford.edu/people/karli-cerankowski|website=gender.stanford.edu|accessdate=5 June 2017}} ==Publications== With Megan Milks, Cerankowski co-edited ''Asexualities: Feminist and Queer Perspectives'' ([[Routledge]], 2014),{{cite book|last1=Cerankowski|first1=Karli June|last2=Milks|first2=Megan|title=Asexualities : feminist and queer perspectives|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0415714427}} one of the earliest collections of essays on the study of [[asexuality]]. Cerankowski's writings have been published in ''[[Feminist Studies]]''{{cite journal|last1=Cerankowski|first1=Karli June|last2=Milks|first2=Megan|title=New Orientations: Asexuality and Its Implications for Theory and Practice|journal=Feminist Studies|date=2010|volume=36|issue=3|pages=650–664|jstor=27919126}} and ''[[WSQ (journal)|WSQ: Women's Studies Quarterly]]''.{{cite journal|last1=Cerankowski|first1=Karli June|title=Queer Dandy Style: The Cultural Politics of Tim Gunn's Asexuality|journal=WSQ: Women's Studies Quarterly|date=15 June 2013|volume=41|issue=1|pages=226–244|doi=10.1353/wsq.2013.0059|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/510272|accessdate=5 June 2017|issn=1934-1520}} ==See also== * [[List of LGBT writers]] * [[List of Stanford University people]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Worldcat id|id=lccn-n2013066714}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cerankowski, Karli June}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Gender studies academics]] [[Category:LGBT studies academics]] [[Category:LGBT writers from the United States]] [[Category:Queer writers]] [[Category:Oberlin College faculty]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Ohio]]

[[Philipp Gerlach]]
[[Johann Heinrich Strack]]
others | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | awards = | url = | references = }} The '''Kronprinzenpalais''' ('''Crown Prince's Palace''') is a landmark [[Neo-classical architecture|late Neoclassical]]-style building at one end of [[Unter den Linden]] in [[Berlin]]. It was a palace of the ruling [[House of Hohenzollern|Hohenzollern]] house of Prussia until the abolition of the monarchy at the end of [[World War I]]. It then became an annexe of the [[National Gallery (Berlin)|Berlin National Gallery]], housing a preeminent collection of modern art. It was closed by the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]] and the building was destroyed in [[World War II]]. It was rebuilt in 1968 and used by [[East Germany]] as a guest house for official visitors to their capital of [[East Berlin]]. Since [[German reunification]] it has been used for exhibitions and cultural events. ==Earliest uses== [[Johann Arnold Nering]] created the building in 1663–69 as the private residence of Cabinet Secretary Johann Martitz, converting an existing middle-class house.Hans Reuther, ''Barock in Berlin: Meister und Werke der Berliner Baukunst 1640-1786'', Berlin: Rembrandt, 1969, {{OCLC|476510798}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mMtDAQAAIAAJ&q=Johann+Martitz+Kronprinzenpalais&dq=Johann+Martitz+Kronprinzenpalais&source=bl&ots=szwLGJ5XX_&sig=u18ZmErXAwsz-pAkTasjEyfhvKQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=07c7UNz6E6jFigL05IDwBg&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ p. 129] {{de icon}}Paul Wietzorek, ''Das historische Berlin: Bilder erzählen'', Petersberg: Imhof, 2005, {{ISBN|9783865680501}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=fU5oAAAAMAAJ&q=Kronprinzenpalais+Nering&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+Nering&source=bl&ots=q_pWTVJw2q&sig=NwbD8N0qDKKPjqAfWfwSZdsgDNc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PAZCUOurN4qyiQKVhYHYDw&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBjgK p. 148] {{de icon}} From 1706 to 1732, it was the official residence of the Governor of Berlin.[http://www.stadtentwicklung.berlin.de/cgi-bin/hidaweb/getdoc.pl?DOK_TPL=lda_doc.tpl&KEY=obj%2009095949 Kronprinzenpalais], Denkmale in Berlin, Senatsverwaltung für Stadtentwicklung und Umwelt {{de icon}} ==Remodelling and use as a royal palace== [[File:Kronprinzenpalais Berlin vor 1856.jpg|thumb|170px|Kronprinzenpalais after its first rebuilding]] [[File:AK01404a.jpg|thumb|170px|Kronprinzenpalais after remodelling by [[Johann Heinrich Strack]], ''c''. 1890]] [[File:Fotothek df pk 0000287 020.jpg|thumb|170px|Kronprinzenpalais in ruins, 1947]] In 1732, [[Philipp Gerlach]] remodelled the building in [[Baroque architecture|baroque]] style with a protruding central bay and a carriage drive rising to the front entrance, to serve as a residence for the Crown Prince, the future King [[Frederick the Great|Frederick II]]. He and his wife [[Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Bevern|Elisabeth Christine]] stayed there only intermittently before his accession to the throne in 1740, after which he took up residence in part of the [[Stadtschloss, Berlin|royal palace]]. He gave the Kronprinzenpalais to his brother [[Prince Augustus William of Prussia|Augustus William]]; after Augustus William's death in 1758, his widow continued to use it until 1780. The building was then renovated and refurnished in Neoclassical style (with furniture from Prussia rather than France) and became the residence of Crown Prince Frederick William (the future [[Frederick William III of Prussia|Frederick William III]]) and his wife [[Louise of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Louise]], who lived there with their children and [[Sophie Marie von Voss|Countess Voss]], who had an apartment near the entrance.Daniel Schönpflug, ''Luise von Preußen: Königin der Herzen; eine Biographie'', Munich: Beck, 2010, {{ISBN|9783406598135}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=F-j1liS4YbYC&pg=PA109&lpg=PA109&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+Statuen&source=bl&ots=ye_97gYlIu&sig=ptdBEBsG9ZBCRRxcSlafnswX89c&hl=en&sa=X&ei=w2U7UPXENabwiwLah4GIBg&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Kronprinzenpalais%20Statuen&f=false pp. 109–11] {{de icon}} They remained there after he became king and the Palace was now called ''Königliches Palais'' (Royal Palace).Brian Ladd, ''The Companion Guide to Berlin'', Woodbridge, Suffolk/Rochester, New York: Companion Guides/Boydell & Brewer, 2004, {{ISBN|9781900639286}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=MY0udx6aJroC&pg=PA32&dq=National+Gallery+Berlin+Crown+Prince%27s+Palace&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ffXQT7qlOqjL2QXAp_iCDw&ved=0CFYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 32]. [[Johann Gottfried Schadow]] created his double statue of Crown Princess Louise and her sister [[Frederica of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Frederica]], the ''Prinzessinnengruppe'', in the palace in 1795–97. The future [[William I, German Emperor|Emperor William I]] was born there on 22 March 1797.Helmut Seier, "Wilhelm I. Deutscher Kaiser (1871–1888)", in ''Die Kaiser der Neuzeit, 1519-1918: Heiliges Römisches Reich, Österreich, Deutschland'', ed. Anton Schindling and Walter Ziegler, Munich: Beck, 1990, {{ISBN|9783406343957}}, pp. 395–409, [https://books.google.com/books?id=uTg43WtvPnQC&pg=PA395&lpg=PA395&dq=Wilhelm+I+Kronprinzenpalais+geboren&source=bl&ots=e0y0y27n8H&sig=uluUn_NwuSBcD40mzWnO_fsjF7c&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Zcw7UN7zNKariALNr4HACQ&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Wilhelm%20I%20Kronprinzenpalais%20geboren&f=false p. 395] {{de icon}} In the early 19th century, [[Karl Friedrich Schinkel]] renovated several rooms in the palace; he also designed an extension over the Oberwallstraße connecting the palace to the ''Kronprinzessinnenpalais'' (Crown Princesses' Palace), where the king's three daughters were living; this was built in 1811 by [[Heinrich Gentz]] in association with his remodelling of the exterior of the Prinzessinenpalais.Ingrid Nowel, ''Berlin: die alte neue Metropole; Architektur und Kunst, Geschichte und Literatur'', Dumont Kunst-Reiseführer, 6th ed. Ostfildern: DuMont, 2009, {{ISBN|9783770155774}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=1AyuAohwzIkC&pg=PA123&lpg=PA123&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+Strack&source=bl&ots=-2CWg7QLRS&sig=7Du0iEzS_Eiz7gD2zW2kR73U_OQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fME7UM31BumliQKhooHIDw&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Kronprinzenpalais%20Strack&f=false pp. 123–24] {{de icon}} After Louise's early death, Frederick William maintained a family shrine to her in the palace.Eva Giloi, ''Monarchy, Myth, and Material Culture in Germany 1750–1950'', New studies in European history, Cambridge/New York: Cambridge University, 2011, {{ISBN|9780521761987}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=3DFPBIFKk7YC&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+Statuen&source=bl&ots=QyobDOdYt1&sig=BxuFgVHge3rWCf0e24XOkDALLP8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=w2U7UPXENabwiwLah4GIBg&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=snippet&q=Luise%27s%20relics%20in%20the%20Kronprinzenpalais%20in%20a%20family%20shrine&f=false p. 54]. The main building was known as the ''Königliches Palais'' (Royal Palace) until 1840; after 1840, when the king died, it was known as the former Royal Palace, and was not used by any members of the royal family; during the reign of [[Frederick William IV of Prussia|Frederick William IV]], it housed court officials, and [[Rudolf Lepke]], who founded a major auction house, grew up there.Giloi, [https://books.google.com/books?id=3DFPBIFKk7YC&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+Statuen&source=bl&ots=QyobDOdYt1&sig=BxuFgVHge3rWCf0e24XOkDALLP8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=w2U7UPXENabwiwLah4GIBg&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=snippet&q=Kronprinzenpalais%2C%20which%20housed%20court%20officials&f=false p. 196]. In 1856–57, [[Johann Heinrich Strack]] extensively rebuilt the palace for William I's son, Prince Frederick William (the future [[Kaiser Frederick III]]), giving it substantially its present appearance. Strack replaced the [[mansard roof]] with a third storey with [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] pillars, and added neo-classical details to the façade, whose columns he changed from [[Tuscan order|Tuscan]] to Corinthian. The four statues above the entrance remained, but he added a tall columned [[portico]] surmounted by a balcony. He also built a setback addition on the east side of the building, with a [[colonnade]] on its Unter den Linden and Niederlagstraße sides. After 1861, when Frederick William's father acceded to the throne and he became Crown Prince, the building was once again known as the Kronprinzenpalais; he resided there with his wife [[Victoria, Princess Royal|Princess Victoria]], daughter of England's [[Queen Victoria]]. Their eldest son, who would be the last German Emperor as [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]], was born in the palace on 27 January 1859.John C. G. Röhl, "Wilhelm II. Deutscher Kaiser (1888–1918)", in ''Die Kaiser der Neuzeit, 1519-1918: Heiliges Römisches Reich, Österreich, Deutschland'', ed. Anton Schindling and Walter Ziegler, Munich: Beck, 1990, {{ISBN|9783406343957}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=uTg43WtvPnQC&pg=PA395&lpg=PA395&dq=Wilhelm+I+Kronprinzenpalais+geboren&source=bl&ots=e0y0y27n8H&sig=uluUn_NwuSBcD40mzWnO_fsjF7c&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Zcw7UN7zNKariALNr4HACQ&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=snippet&q=27.%20Januar&f=false p. 419] {{de icon}} Princess Victoria welcomed artists and scholars to the palace, including [[Heinrich von Angeli]], [[Anton von Werner]] and [[Adolph von Menzel]].[http://www.kaiserinfriedrich.de/kfmaler2.html Kaiserin Friedrich als Künstlerin: Künstlerische Bestrebungen am preußischen Hof in Berlin], Kaiserin Friedrich.de {{de icon}} However, after Frederick III's death in 1888 following a 99-day reign, she was usually at her new residence, [[Schlosshotel Kronberg|Schloß Friedrichshof]], and the palace was rarely used. Beginning in 1905, it was used as a winter residence by Wilhelm II's heir, [[Wilhelm, German Crown Prince|Crown Prince Wilhelm]], and his wife [[Duchess Cecilie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Crown Princess Cecilie]]. During the [[German Revolution of 1918–1919|November revolution]] in Berlin in 1918, revolutionary leaders addressed the crowd from the entrance ramp of the palace.[http://www.dhm.de/gos-cgi-bin/dbsatz.pl?Objekt=ju004511&Datenbank=allwww "Nach der Ausrufung der Republik in Berlin"], photograph by Otto Haeckel, 9 November 1918, at [[German Historical Museum]] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}[http://xserve04.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/einsteinausstellung/SC31_MOD47_SEQ518_SL2006_en.html "Revolution in Berlin 9 November 1918"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130106004353/http://xserve04.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/einsteinausstellung/SC31_MOD47_SEQ518_SL2006_en.html |date=6 January 2013 }}, the same picture at Wissenschaft am Abgrund: Weltkrieg und Revolution, slideshow with instructional captions. ==Modern annexe of the National Gallery== After the dissolution of the monarchy, the palace became a possession of the State of Prussia, which gave it to the National Gallery in 1919 to house its drawing collection.According to Giloi, [https://books.google.com/books?id=3DFPBIFKk7YC&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+Statuen&source=bl&ots=QyobDOdYt1&sig=BxuFgVHge3rWCf0e24XOkDALLP8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=w2U7UPXENabwiwLah4GIBg&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=snippet&q=Kronprinzenpalais%20and%20its%20ajoining%20Prinzessinnenpalais%20were%20awarded%20to%20the%20National%20Gallery&f=false p. 345], the Prinzessinnenpalais as well.Jesús Pedro Lorente, tr. Rosa Anía and Noel Murphy, ''The Museums of Contemporary Art: Notion and Development'', Farnham / Burlington, Vermont: Ashgate, 2011, {{ISBN|9781409405863}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=VQp64nNTWxAC&pg=PA112&lpg=PA112&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+November-revolution&source=bl&ots=RhNRrXpMh9&sig=6J4C_cKlgux8IOnvkmTMCfGGr2U&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BjA5UPfxCqXHigKWxoGADw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Kronprinzenpalais%20November-revolution&f=false p. 112]. The director, [[Ludwig Justi]], used this annexe to the existing building (now known as the [[Alte Nationalgalerie]]) to house a new department devoted to living artists, the ''Galerie der Lebenden'', something which he had proposed the previous year and which contemporary artists themselves had been demanding.Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, ''Art treasures of the Berlin State Museums'', New York: Abrams, 1965, {{OCLC|475266}}, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=ffXQT7qlOqjL2QXAp_iCDw&id=tZwzAQAAIAAJ&dq=National+Gallery+Berlin+Crown+Prince%27s+Palace&q=in+1919%2C+by+the+acquisition+for+exhibition+purposes+of+the+former+Kronprinzenpalais+%28Crown+Prince%27s+Palace%29#search_anchor p. 65].Françoise Forster-Hahn, ''Spirit of an Age: Nineteenth-Century Paintings from the Nationalgalerie, Berlin'', Exhibition catalogue, [[National Gallery, London]], [[National Gallery of Art, Washington]], London: National Gallery, 2001, {{ISBN|9781857099607}}, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=SP7QT7uSFojg2gXQy8GWDw&id=8udOAAAAYAAJ&dq=Nationalgalerie+II%2C+Kronprinzenpalais&q=ln+1919+Justi+secured+the+Kronprinzenpalais+%28Crown+Prince%27s+palace%29%2C+which+had+now+lost+its+purpose%2C+as+an+outhouse+of+the+Nationalgalerie+for+contemporary+art.+Until+its+closure+by+the+National+Socialists+in+1937+the+works+shown+there#search_anchor p. 55].Joan Weinstein, ''The End of Expressionism: Art and the November Revolution in Germany, 1918–19'', Chicago: University of Chicago, 1990, {{ISBN|9780226890593}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=bwgTcfxyzokC&pg=PA267&dq=Geschichte+der+Nationalgalerie+Berlin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2a_LT5ygHKrq2AW9xOnaCw&sqi=2&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=opened%20in%20August%201919%20with%20around%20one%20hundred%20fifty%20works&f=false p. 85]. This opened on 4 August 1919Annegret Janda, ''Das Schicksal einer Sammlung: Aufbau und Zerstörung der Neuen Abteilung der Nationalgalerie im ehemaligen Kronprinzen-Palais unter den Linden, 1918–1945'', in association with exhibition, Nationalgalerie (East Berlin), [[Neue Gesellschaft für Bildende Kunst]], Staatliche Museen (East Berlin), Berlin: Neue Gesellschaft für Bildende Kunst, 1988, {{ISBN|9783926796011}}, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=tz81UK3-BuiSiALBkoGQDQ&id=C9jpAAAAMAAJ&dq=Janda%2C+%22Das+Schicksal+einer+Sammlung%22&q=4.+August#search_anchor p. 3] {{de icon}} with approximately 150 paintings and sculptures including naturalistic and French [[Impressionism|Impressionist]] works, a sculpture by [[Auguste Rodin|Rodin]] (in a room retaining the old palace décor, which also featured paintings by [[Paul Cézanne|Cézanne]], [[Vincent van Gogh|Van Gogh]], and [[Édouard Manet|Manet]]), works representing both the establishment ''Verein Berliner Künstler'' and the [[Berlin Secession]], and on the top floor in a temporary display, works by members of [[Die Brücke]] and other [[Expressionism|Expressionist]]s.Uwe Prell, "Berlin—Bühne des Wandels—Ein Reisebericht", PhD dissertation, [[Free University of Berlin]], [http://www.diss.fu-berlin.de/diss/servlets/MCRFileNodeServlet/FUDISS_derivate_000000001288/3_Kapitel3_kl.pdf?hosts= Chapter 3] (pdf) p. 284 {{de icon}} This was the first state promotion in Germany of Expressionist works, which were unpopular with large numbers of the public.Elizabeth M. Grady, "The Popular Opposition: Politicizing Modern Art in the National Gallery in Berlin, 1918–1933", in Julie F. Codell, ed., ''The Political Economy of Art: Making the Nation of Culture'', Cranbury, New Jersey: Fairleigh Dickinson University/Associated University Presses, 2008, {{ISBN|9780838641682}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=srEYIpCHd0IC&pg=PA96&dq=Nationalgalerie+Kronprinzenpalais&hl=en&sa=X&ei=TgPRT9FK4ezSAZWZzNMP&sqi=2&ved=0CEcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Nationalgalerie%20Kronprinzenpalais&f=false p. 96]. The gallery was a pioneer of the museum of contemporary art; in the judgement of the assistant director of the National Gallery at the time, the collection was superior to that of all other German galleries then collecting modern art.Stephanie Barron, ''Degenerate Art: The Fate of the Avant-Garde in Nazi Germany'', Exhibition catalogue, [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]], [[Art Institute of Chicago]], New York: Abrams, 1991, {{ISBN|9780810936539}}, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=TgPRT9FK4ezSAZWZzNMP&sqi=2&id=X9rpAAAAMAAJ&dq=Nationalgalerie+Kronprinzenpalais&q=Alfred+Hentzen+characterized+the+collection+as+follows%3A+%22The+Neue+Abteilung+in+the+former+Kronprinzen-+Palais+surpassed+all+the+other+forty+or+so+museums+in+Germany+that+were#search_anchor p. 116]. It served as a model for later institutions, notably the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York, which opened two years after its first director, [[Alfred H. Barr, Jr.]], visited the Kronprinzenpalais in 1927.Forster-Hahn, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=nfo4ULy4EIqzigLb4YCwDQ&id=8udOAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Kronprinzenpalais%22+%22Museum+of+Modern+Art%22&q=With+its+alternation+between+galleries+devoted+to+a+single+artist+and+major+special+exhibitions+of+the+very+latest+artistic+phenomena+the+Kronprinzenpalais+attracted+the+admiration+of+the+young+Alfred+Barn+the+Museum+of+Modern+Art+founded+by#search_anchor p. 16].Modris Eksteins, ''Solar Dance: Genius, Forgery and the Crisis of Truth in the Modern Age'', Toronto: Knopf Canada, 2012, {{ISBN|9780307398598}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=qozSsJ_9hrIC&pg=PT137&lpg=PT137&dq=%22Kronprinzenpalais%22+%22Museum+of+Modern+Art%22&source=bl&ots=p4qv55svJM&sig=2fyepBjHKQML5v6EZm4n96Epwp0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nfo4ULy4EIqzigLb4YCwDQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Kronprinzenpalais%22%20%22Museum%20of%20Modern%20Art%22&f=false n.p.]: Barr wrote to the head of the National Gallery, [[Ludwig Justi]]: "Our institution seeks to fulfil the function of a Kronprinzenpalais!" On the other hand, the art critic [[Karl Scheffler]], who favoured Impressionism and disliked Expressionism, attacked Justi for opening the contemporary art gallery, publishing a book in 1921 with the title ''Berliner Museumskrieg'' (Berlin Museum War).[http://www.dictionaryofarthistorians.org/schefflerk.htm "Scheffler, Karl"], ''Dictionary of Art Historians'', retrieved 27 August 2012; Karl Scheffler, ''Berliner Museumskrieg'', Berlin: Cassirer, 1921, {{OCLC|251357313}} {{de icon}} After the Nazis [[Machtergreifung|came to power]] in 1933, there was an initial period of tolerance of modern art, but then Hitler ordered the galleries to be "cleansed" of it, in particular the Kronprinzenpalais.[[Jonathan Petropoulos]], ''Art as Politics in the Third Reich'', Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina, 1996, {{ISBN|9780807822401}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsKJBgL2&sig=_eFlFDRAowO2CTh83R_upVbvq1o&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=08Q4UKW1L-KEjALRq4GgDw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=The%20crap%20must%20be%20cleaned%20from%20the%20Kronprinzenpalais&f=false p. 48]: Goebbels wrote in his diary on 15 December 1935: "With the Führer at midday.... The crap must be cleansed from the Kronprinzenpalais." In May 1936, works from the Ismar Littmann collection of Expressionist art which had been confiscated by the [[Gestapo]] from a Berlin auction house were burnt in the furnace.Janda, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=tz81UK3-BuiSiALBkoGQDQ&id=C9jpAAAAMAAJ&dq=Janda%2C+%22Das+Schicksal+einer+Sammlung%22&q=Heizung#search_anchor p. 69].Anja Heuss, ''Das Schicksal der jüdischen Kunstsammlung von Ismar Littmann. [[Eberhard Hanfstaengl]], the then director of the National Gallery, was ordered to set aside only a few "historically valuable" works and saved five paintings and ten drawings.Jonathan Petropoulos, ''The Faustian Bargain: The Art World in Nazi Germany'', New York: Oxford University, 2000, {{ISBN|9780195129649}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=uhaXdZAeaVQC&pg=PA16&lpg=PA16&dq=Alois+Schardt,+Berlin+Nationalgalerie&source=bl&ots=GngXFFENPK&sig=p1eKpJMSy5r3vaCTQiAKxPpFHHQ&hl=en#v=snippet&q=Littmann&f=false p. 287, note 68, p. 68]. The Expressionist gallery was closed in October 1936, after the [[1936 Summer Olympics|Berlin Olympics]] had ended, as a "hotbed of [[cultural Bolshevism]]".Petropoulos, ''Art as Politics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsKJBgL2&sig=_eFlFDRAowO2CTh83R_upVbvq1o&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=08Q4UKW1L-KEjALRq4GgDw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=closure%20of%20the%20modern%20section%20of%20the%20Kronprinzenpalais%20%28Nationalgalerie%29%20on%2030%20October%201936&f=false pp. 60–61].[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-46477771.html "Magere Schultern"], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', 9 September 1968 {{de icon}}Mortimer G. National Gallery Director Justi had been forced out in the 1933 purge of ideologically suspect academics and civil servants; his successor, [[Alois Schardt]], was forced to resign after [[Bernhard Rust]], the Nazi Minister of Education for Prussia, who had responsibility for museums, visited the modern art gallery;Petropoulos, ''Art as Politics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsLBCcD1&sig=OC-skA5VjHOAiFD0x1cIK_Py8C0&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=-hQ5ULm_EMWYiQK81IHgAw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=upon%20inspecting%20the%20modern%20section%20of%20the%20gallery%20in%20October%20of%20that%20year%2C%20he%20ordered%20Schardt%27s%20resignation&f=false p. 20]. he was in turn succeeded by Hanfstaengl, who was also forced to resign after refusing to meet with [[Adolf Ziegler]] and his commission charged with identifying and removing the "degenerate" artworks.Petropoulos, ''Faustian Bargain'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=OSfkIvDejykC&pg=PA16&dq=Nationalgalerie+Berlin+Hanfstaengl&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MZ7QT-Eshp7aBZTZzd4M&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Nationalgalerie%20Berlin%20Hanfstaengl&f=false p. 16].Rosebrock, [https://books.google.com/books?id=uqV8H_RG2CwC&pg=PA75&dq=Nationalgalerie+Berlin+Nachkriegszeit&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dVnST87OOMLQ2wX30q2gDw&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=war%20seine%20baldige%20Absetzung%20so%20gut%20wie%20entschieden&f=false pp. 73–74]. The commission made two "cleansing" visits to the Kronprinzenpalais: on 7 July before the exhibition openedPetropoulos, ''Art as Politics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsLBCcD1&sig=OC-skA5VjHOAiFD0x1cIK_Py8C0&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=-hQ5ULm_EMWYiQK81IHgAw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=managed%20to%20%22cleanse%22%20the%20Nationalgalerie&f=false p. 56]. and again in August. Some members of the commission were at first reluctant to purge the works of [[August Macke]] and [[Franz Marc]], both of whom had died fighting in the First World War; they were ultimately also removed, but works by Marc including ''[[Tower of Blue Horses]]'' were removed from the ''Entartete Kunst'' exhibition before it moved from Munich to Berlin.Petropoulos, ''Art as Politics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsLBCcD1&sig=OC-skA5VjHOAiFD0x1cIK_Py8C0&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=-hQ5ULm_EMWYiQK81IHgAw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=August%20Macke%20and%20Franz%20Marc&f=false p. 57]. The National Gallery was compensated [[Reichsmark|RM]] 150,000 for ''[[Daubigny's Garden|The Garden of Daubigny]]'' by [[Van Gogh]] and RM 15,000 for four paintings by [[Paul Signac]] and [[Edvard Munch]] by [[Göring]], who took a group of 13 modern paintings to offer them privately for sale through an art dealer he knew,Petropoulos, ''Art as Politics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsLBCcD1&sig=OC-skA5VjHOAiFD0x1cIK_Py8C0&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=-hQ5ULm_EMWYiQK81IHgAw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=Garden%20of%20Daubigny&f=false pp. 79–80]. and roughly one sixth of its total loss of over RM 1 million after the official auctions of "degenerate art" in Switzerland.Petropoulos, ''Art as Politics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsLBCcD1&sig=OC-skA5VjHOAiFD0x1cIK_Py8C0&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=-hQ5ULm_EMWYiQK81IHgAw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=received%20approximately%20a%20sixth%20of%20its%20total%20loss&f=false p. 81]. Later in 1937, the building became the seat of the [[Prussian Academy of Arts]], whose building in [[Pariser Platz]] had been requisitioned by [[Albert Speer]]'s office.Petropoulos, ''Art as Politics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsKJBgL2&sig=_eFlFDRAowO2CTh83R_upVbvq1o&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=08Q4UKW1L-KEjALRq4GgDw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=make%20space%20in%20the%20Akademie%27s%20Pariser%20Platz%20building&f=false p. 73], [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjQO61bvE7gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Petropoulos,+Art+as+Politics&source=bl&ots=LuMsKJBgL2&sig=_eFlFDRAowO2CTh83R_upVbvq1o&hl=en&src=bmrr&sa=X&ei=08Q4UKW1L-KEjALRq4GgDw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=The%20Akademie%20moved%20into%20the%20%22cleansed%22%20Kronprinzenpalais&f=false p. 335, note 100]. The Director of the [[Konzerthaus Berlin|Schauspielhaus]] theatre in the [[Gendarmenmarkt]], [[Gustaf Gründgens]], also temporarily had his office in the building.[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-14334169.html "Tanz auf dem Vulkan"], ''Der Spiegel'', 28 September 1981 {{de icon}} In March 1945, the Kronprinzenpalais was gutted in an Allied bomb attack. Until 1958, a ballet school used a remaining rear section, but the site was entirely cleared in 1961. Nikolaus Bernau, "Das Kronprinzenpalais Unter den Linden. Ein Denkmal der DDR-Moderne", ''Museumsjournal Berlin'' 1 (1999) 4–9 ([http://schlossdebatte.de/?p=77 online at Schlosdebatte.de]) {{de icon}} ==Reconstruction and postwar uses== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-W0423-0008, Berlin, Palais Unter den Linden.jpg|thumb|170px|Reconstructed Palais Unter den Linden, 1980]] In 1968–69, to complete the restoration of the south side of Unter den Linden and make a suitable visual transition to the newly completed Foreign Ministry skyscraper (since demolished) and the rest of the East German government district immediately to the east, the Kronprinzenpalais was rebuilt with approximately the same exterior appearance as after Strack's work by [[Richard Paulick]], a former associate of [[Walter Gropius]] who had already rebuilt the Kronprinzessinnenpalais and the [[Berlin State Opera|State Opera]],Bayerische Akademie der Wissenschaften, Historische Kommission, ''Neue deutsche Biographie'' volume 20 ''Pagenstecher - Püterich'', Berlin: Duncker & Humblot, 2001, {{ISBN|9783428002016}}, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=qTk1UNWTKcjdigLjn4HQAg&id=CabpAAAAMAAJ&dq=Kronprinzenpalais+Die+Bau-+und+Kunstdenkmale+in+der+DDR&q=Kronprinzenpalais%2C+1967-69#search_anchor p. 125] {{de icon}} and Werner Prendel. (Paulick had originally intended to rebuild it as it had been in 1733, for use as a modern museum, music school, or performance space, but conceptions of the role of the area changed in the 1960s.) However, the top floor was extended to include the east wing to improve the building's proportions, and the interior (1968–70) was modern. As the ''Palais Unter den Linden'', it was used as a guest house by the Magistrat, the governing executive of [[East Berlin]]. The [[German Reunification|Unification Agreement]] was signed there on 31 August 1990, after which the [[Senate of Berlin]] took possession of the building. The garden, which extends from Oberwallstraße to Niederlagstraße and has underground parking garages under part of it, was newly laid out in 1969–70 by W. Hinkefuß and descends in terraces to a central lawn, and then rises again in further terraces to a restaurant called the Schinkelklause, which incorporates pieces of terracotta and an entrance from Schinkel's [[Bauakademie]], which was partially destroyed in World War II and demolished around 1960. The sculptures in the garden are by {{Interlanguage link multi|Senta Baldamus|de}}, [[Gerhard Thierse]] and {{Interlanguage link multi|Gerhard Lichtenfelds|de}}. From 1998 to 2003, the Kronprinzenpalais was used as temporary exhibit space by the [[Deutsches Historisches Museum]] while its primary building, the [[Zeughaus]] across the street,Christiane Kruse, ''Berlin Heute / Today / Aujourd'hui'', Munich: Prestel, 2002, {{ISBN|9783791326467}}, p. 56, photo p. 57. was under renovation. It continues to be used for exhibitions and other cultural events. For example, in 2005 it housed an exhibition on [[Albert Einstein]],[http://einsteinexhibit.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/en/Exhibition/palais The Location: The Kronprinzenpalais] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511223625/http://einsteinexhibit.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/en/Exhibition/palais# |date=2011-05-11 }}, Albert Einstein—Chief Engineer of the Universe, [[Max Planck Institute]], 2005, retrieved 27 August 2012. and in spring 2006 [[Joshua Sobol]]'s polydrama ''[[Alma (play)|Alma]]'', on [[Alma Mahler]], played scenes simultaneously in various rooms, which required temporarily reconstructing the historical appearance of the interior. In 2006 the building housed ''Erzwungene Wege—Flucht und Vertreibung im Europa des 20. Jahrhunderts'', a controversial exhibition on expulsions of Germans in 20th-century Europe organised by the [[Federation of Expellees]],Severin Weiland, [http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/ausstellung-erzwungene-wege-auf-schmalem-grat-a-431026.html "Ausstellung 'Erzwungene Wege': Auf schmalem Grat"], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', 10 August 2006 {{de icon}}[http://www.zeitgeschichte-online.de/portals/_rainbow/documents/pdf/presse_erzwungene_wege.pdf Pressestimmen zur Ausstellung 'Erzwungene Wege—Flucht und Vertreibung im Europa des 20. Jahrhunderts'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320023426/http://www.zeitgeschichte-online.de/portals/_rainbow/documents/pdf/presse_erzwungene_wege.pdf# |date=2009-03-20 }} Zeitgeschichte-online, 7 September 2006, retrieved 22 August 2012 (pdf) {{de icon}} and in March–June 2012 it housed a three-part exhibition dealing more broadly with forced exile and including ''Erzwungene Wege'' as one of its components.Katharina Klotz, "Kronprinzenpalais: ''Heimatweh—Eine Trilogie''", ''Museumsjournal'' 2 (2012) p. 90 {{de icon}} The building is a Berlin historic landmark. {{clear}} {{multiple image | align = center | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = The four statues over the entrance | image1 = Kronprinzenpalais Berlin statue1.jpg | width1 = 150 | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Kronprinzenpalais Berlin statue2.jpg | width2 = 150 | alt2 = | caption2 = | image3 = Kronprinzenpalais Berlin statue3.jpg | width3 = 150 | alt3 = | caption3 = | image4 = Kronprinzenpalais Berlin statue4.jpg | width4 = 150 | alt4 = | caption4 = }} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Paul Seidel. "Zur Geschichte des Kronprinzen-Palais in Berlin, insbesondere der ehemaligen Wohnung der Königin Luise". ''Hohenzollern-Jahrbuch'' 11 (1907) 206–57 {{de icon}} * Jörg Haspel. "Rekonstruktion als städtebauliche Denkmalpflege? Das Kronprinzenpalais in Berlin". In ''Rekonstruktion in der Denkmalpflege. Überlegungen, Definitionen, Erfahrungsberichte''. Ed. Juliane Kirschbaum and Annegret Klein. Schriftenreihe des Deutschen Nationalkomitees für Denkmalschutz 57. Bonn: Deutsches Nationalkomitee für Denkmalschutz, 1998. {{OCLC|470203880}}. pp. 75–81 {{de icon}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Kronprinzenpalais (Berlin)|Kronprinzenpalais}} * [http://www.alma-mahler.com/deutsch/gallery/photo_archive_pan_berlin.html 360° panoramas of Kronprinzenpalais], exteriors and historically reconstructed interiors for performance of ''[[Alma (play)|Alma]]'' * [http://www.alma-mahler.com/archiv_berlin_deutsch/info_berlin/kronprinzenpalais/kaiser_koenige.html "Kaiser und Könige"], illustrated history of the building to 1919 at the ''Alma'' site {{de icon}} {{Prussian royal residences}} {{coord|52|31|02|N|13|23|49|E|type:landmark_scale:1000|display=title}} [[Category:Houses completed in 1669]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Mitte]] [[Category:Palaces in Berlin]] [[Category:Royal residences in Berlin]] [[Category:Prussian cultural sites]] [[Category:Decorative arts museums in Germany]] [[Category:Museums in Berlin]] [[Category:Rebuilt buildings and structures in Berlin]] [[Category:1669 establishments in the Holy Roman Empire]] [[Category:17th-century establishments in Brandenburg-Prussia]]
